questions.text: A child finds difficulty to spell and read, otherwise his IQ is normal, and interacts well with parents and friends. Vision is normal. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Dyslexia is characterized by persistent difficulty in word recognition, spelling, and decoding despite average or above-average intelligence and normal sensory function.
  • The core deficit is in phonological processing, leading to slow, effortful reading, frequent misreading, and poor spelling.
  • Social interaction and overall cognitive functioning remain intact.
  • Onset typically in early school years; not due to sensory deficits, intellectual disability, or inadequate instruction.
  • Assessment:
    • Use structured reading batteries to assess phonological awareness, decoding, and fluency.
    • Rule out vision or hearing impairments and screen for comorbid ADHD or language disorders.

Explanation of other options:

  • Autism(option A) involves deficits in social communication and restricted, repetitive behaviors. Reading difficulty is not isolated and social reciprocity is impaired.
  • ADHD(Option B) is characterized by inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity, academic struggles are secondary to attentional deficits, not specific phonological processing errors.
  • Asperger syndrome(Option D) is now classified under Autism Spectrum Disorder; marked by social communication impairments and restricted interests, not isolated reading/spelling problems.

questions.text: What will be the preferred drug to treat ADHD in a 8 year old boy, whose father has a history of substance abuse?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Atomoxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) approved for the treatment of ADHD in children, adolescents and adults.
  • It works by inhibiting the presynaptic norepinephrine transporter, enhancing noradrenergic transmission in the prefrontal cortex (improves attention and executive function).
  • Because atomoxetine does not produce stimulant-like effects (euphoria, reinforcing dopamine release), it is the preferred choice when there is personal/family history of substance abuse.
  • Side effects:
    • abdominal discomfort,
    • decreased appetite with weight loss,
    • irritability
    • mood swings
    • dizziness and rarely elevated liver enzymes.
  • May be combined with psychosocial interventions (behavior therapy, structured classroom support).

Explanation of other options:

  • Methylphenidate(Option A): Stimulant and first-line for ADHD in many cases. High abuse potential so not preferred in patients with personal or family history of substance abuse
  • Risperidone(Option B): Antipsychotic, not a first-line treatment for ADHD Used for comorbid aggression, autism-related irritability, or severe behavior disturbances not appropriate as monotherapy for ADHD
  • Modafinil(Option D): A wakefulness-promoting agent, not a first line treatment.

Reference: Indian Journal of Psychiatry, CPG for ADHD

questions.text: A 3 year old girl is brought to OPD with features of hand wringing stereotyped movements, impaired language and communication development, breath holding spells, poor social skills and deceleration of head after six months of age. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rett syndrome is a progressive condition that has its onset after some months of what appears to be normal development. It is caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene on the X chromosome

  • Initial development appears normal: head circumference is normal at birth, and early milestones are unremarkable.
  • Between 5 and 48 months of age (typically 6-12 months), head growth begins to decelerate, resulting in acquired microcephally.
  • Regression of previously acquired skills: loss of purposeful hand use and spoken language.
  • Emergence of characteristic hand stereotypies: hand-wringing, washing, or clapping movements replace purposeful hand activity.
  • Autonomic and respiratory dysregulation: breath-holding spells, hyperventilation, and apnea episodes occur when the child is awake.
  • Clinical Stages:
    • Early Onset (6-18 months): Subtle developmental slowing, decreased eye contact, irritability.
    • Rapid Regression (1-4 years): Marked loss of hand skills and language, onset of hand stereotypies, social withdrawal.
    • Plateau (2-10 years): Stabilization of deficits, possible improvement in social engagement, persistent motor impairments.
    • Late Motor Deterioration (>10 years): Progressive scoliosis, rigidity, reduced mobility; continued seizures; most individuals remain

Explanation of other options:

  • Heller's syndrome(Option A)- Regression occurs after at least 2 years of normal development across multiple domains; lacks head growth deceleration and characteristic hand-wringing.
  • Asperger syndrome(Option C)- No early developmental regression; language development remains intact, and head growth is normal; primary features are social communication deficits and restricted interests.
  • ADHD(Option D)- Characterized by inattention and hyperactivity without loss of previously acquired developmental milestones, head growth changes, or hand stereotypies.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is recently approved for an autistic spectrum disorder where MECP2 gene is affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The diagnosis is Rett's syndrome
  • Trofinetide is a New drug approved by FDA in March 2023.
  • Trofinetide is a synthetic analog of IGF-1's N-terminal tripeptide that improves synaptic function and reduces neuroinflammation.
  • Approved for Rett's syndrome (MECP2 mutation) based on trials showing gains in communication, motor skills, and behavior.

Explanation of other options:

  • Flibanserin(Option A): A serotonin receptor modulator approved for hypoactive sexual desire disorder (HSDD) in premenopausal women.
  • Bremelanotide(Option B): A melanocortin receptor agonist used for HSDD in premenopausal women, administered as a subcutaneous injection before sexual activity.
  • Zurzuvae (zuranolone)(Option C): A neuroactive steroid and GABA-A receptor positive allosteric modulator, approved for postpartum depression.

choices.text: Can follow simple verbal commands and handle money

questions.text: A child with IQ 50, which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • An IQ of 50 falls within the mild intellectual disability (ID) range (IQ 50-69).
  • Children with mild intellectual disability are typically able to:
    • Follow simple verbal instructions (e.g., "Put the cup down".)
    • Learn practical, age-appropriate tasks such as handling money under supervision.
  • Classification by IQ:
    • Mild ID: IQ 50-69 → Can achieve social and vocational skill, academic up to 6th grade.
    • Moderate ID: IQ 35-49 → Follow simple verbal commands, perform unskilled work, limited academic progress.
    • Severe ID: IQ 20-34 → Basic self-care, minimal communication, require supervision.
    • Profound ID: IQ <20 → Dependent in all areas, minimal communication, may not recognize caregivers.

questions.text: According to DSM-5, making a determination of severity level of intellectual disability includes assessment of functioning in all of the following domains except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • DSM-5 defines severity of intellectual disability primarily by adaptive functioning across three domains:
    • Conceptual (e.g., academic skills, reasoning)
    • Social (e.g., interpersonal communication, empathy)
    • Practical (e.g., personal care, self-management)
  • Theoretical domain is not a recognized adaptive domain for severity determination.
  • Adaptive Functioning vs. IQ:
    • IQ alone no longer dictates severity level; adaptive skills across domains drive classification.
  • Severity Levels (DSM-5):
    • Mild: deficits in one or more domains but can develop social and vocational skills with support.
    • Moderate: noticeable deficits in communication and basic self-care; supervised support required.
    • Severe/Profound: pervasive impairments, limited communication, dependency in all daily activities.

questions.text: Which of the following X chromosome linked genetic disorder is a cause for intellectual disability?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fragile X syndrome is caused by a trinucleotide (CGG) repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome, leading to methylation and silencing of FMR1.
  • Loss of FMR1 protein (FMRP) disrupts synaptic development and plasticity, resulting in intellectual disability.
  • It is the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability and the first X-linked gene identified as a direct cause. It is an X-linked dominant disorder.
  • Clinical Features of Fragile X:
    • Males typically present with moderate intellectual disability, long face, large ears, macroorchidism after puberty, and behavioral issues such as autism-like features.
    • Females may have mild cognitive impairment due to X inactivation.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Molecular testing (PCR or Southern blot) to detect CGG repeat length in FMR1 (>200 repeats = full mutation).
    • Carrier testing for premutation (55-200 repeats) is important in family counseling

Explanation of other options:

  • Turner syndrome(Option A)- 45,X karyotype associated with short stature, ovarian failure, and normal to mildly reduced IQ, not a primary cause of intellectual disability.
  • Klinefelter's syndrome(Option C)- 47,XXY karyotype. Males may have learning difficulties but usually normal to borderline IQ, not a direct cause of intellectual disability.
  • Jacob syndrome(Option D)- 47,XYY karyotype, typically tall stature and possible learning or behavioral issues, but normal to low-normal IQ; not a primary cause of intellectual disability.

choices.text: She is expected to have lower IQ as compared to general population
Verbal performance dissociation would be commonly seen while performing her IQ test
Her mathematical ability is expected to be reduced as compared to general population
Verbal skills would be higher if the X chromosome is paternally derived

questions.text: The following figure is of a 14-year-old girl who has presented with primary amenorrhoea. Which of the following statements is false regarding her intelligence?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The girl in the image appears to have short stature, broad chest with widely spaced nipples, and cubitus valgus which are classic features of Turner Syndrome (45,X). The history of primary amenorrhea at age 14 supports this diagnosis.
  • Girls with Turner syndrome typically have normal full-scale IQ. Cognitive issues, when present, are specific (e.g., in spatial or math skills) rather than global, and do not lower overall IQ into the intellectual disability range.

Explanation of other options:

  • Verbal-performance dissociation is commonly seen(Option B): Turner syndrome is characterized by a distinct verbal-performance split: verbal IQ is average or above, whereas performance IQ (visuospatial, nonverbal reasoning) is significantly lower.
  • Her mathematical ability is expected to be reduced(Option C): Difficulties with visuospatial processing, sequencing, and dyscalculia are well-documented in Turner syndrome and directly impact mathematical learning.
  • Verbal skills would be higher if the X chromosome is paternally derived(Option D): Cognitive testing shows that individuals with a paternal X chromosome (45,Xp) perform better on verbal, social, and arithmetic tasks compared to those with a maternal X (45,Xm), supporting the influence of genomic imprinting.

choices.text: Genomic imprinting with deletion of paternally derived chromosome
Genomic imprinting with deletion of maternally derived chromosome

questions.text: A child presented with features of intellectual disability along with obesity, short stature, hyperphagia and compulsive skin picking. Which genetic abnormality would be usually seen in this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The features on the above question are suggestive of Prader Willi syndrome.
  • Prader-Willi syndrome is believed to result from a small deletion involving chromosome 15. It occurs due to genomic imprinting of paternally derived chromosome.
  • Absence of paternal gene expression leads to hallmark features: hypotonia in infancy, progressing to hyperphagia, obesity, short stature, hypogonadism, intellectual disability, and behavioral issues such as skin picking.
  • Genomic imprinting means that the maternal copy of these genes is normally silenced; loss of the paternal copy results in no functional expression.(Option B ruled out)
  • Clinical Course:
    • Neonatal period: marked hypotonia, poor feeding → failure to thrive.
    • Childhood (after 1-2 years): insatiable appetite → hyperphagia and obesity.
    • Endocrine abnormalities: growth hormone deficiency (short stature), hypogonadism (delayed or incomplete puberty).
    • Behavioral: temper tantrums, skin picking, obsessive-compulsive traits.
    • Cognitive: mild to moderate intellectual disability; learning difficulties.

Explanation of other options:

  • Aneuploidy(Option C): Refers to an abnormal chromosome number (e.g., trisomy 21, 45,X0), not relevant here. PWS is an imprinting disorder, not an aneuploidy
  • Anticipation(Option D): This refers to worsening severity in successive generations seen in disorders like Huntington's or Fragile-X, due to repeat expansions.

choices.text: If dietary modification is started early, the child may have normal intelligence
Intellectual disability has no impact with dietary modification
Intellectual disability shall improve irrespective of when the dietary modification is started

questions.text: Parents of an infant diagnosed with phenylketonuria are being explained the concept of low phenylalanine in diet. With this dietary modification, which of the following changes would be observed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. This results in:
    • Accumulation of phenylalanine (toxic to the brain),
    • Reduced production of tyrosine, which affects neurotransmitter synthesis (dopamine, norepinephrine).
  • An early diagnosis via newborn screening and prompt dietary intervention (low-phenylalanine diet) prevents irreversible brain damage.(Option C ruled out)
  • When phenylalanine levels are kept in the safe range from infancy, children can:
    • Develop normal intelligence(Option B ruled out)
    • Avoid seizures, behavioral problems, and eczema
  • Diet must be maintained for life, especially during brain development (first 5-6 years are critical).
  • A low-phenylalanine diet does not reverse intellectual disability in untreated older children and adolescents with PKU, but the diet does decrease irritability and abnormal electroencephalography (EEG) changes and does increase social responsiveness and attention span.

questions.text: In a X linked recessive disorder presented with intellectual disability and self-injurious behaviour by biting mouth and fingers, what would be the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is a rare disorder caused by a deficiency of an enzyme involved in purine metabolism.
  • The disorder is X-linked; patients have intellectual disability, microcephaly, seizures, choreoathetosis and spasticity.
  • The syndrome is also associated with severe compulsive self-mutilation by biting the mouth and fingers.
  • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is another example of a genetically determined syndrome with a specific, predictable behavioural pattern.
  • Metabolic defect: Hypoxanthine-Guanine Phosphoribosyltransferase

(HPRT) deficiency → impaired purine salvage → uric acid overproduction.

  • Neurologic signs: Dystonia, chorea, spasticity, microcephaly, and seizures.
  • Behavioral management: Protective devices to prevent self-harm, behavioral interventions.
  • Hyperuricemia treatment: Allopurinol to reduce uric acid levels (does not affect neurological or behavioral symptoms).

Explanation of other options:

  • Smith-Magenis Syndrome(Option A): It is caused by deletion on chromosome 17p11
  • Features:
    • Intellectual disability
    • Sleep disturbance
    • Behavioral issues (temper tantrums, self-hugging, head banging)
    • Self-injury is not specific or compulsive, and not X-linked.
  • Williams Syndrome(Option B): It is caused by microdeletion at chromosome 7q11.
  • Features:
    • "Cocktail party" personality
    • Hyperverbal speech
    • Elfin facies, cardiovascular anomalies (supravalvular aortic stenosis)
    • Mild intellectual disability
  • Velocardiofacial Syndrome(Option D): It is caused due to chromosome 22q11 deletion.
  • Features:
    • Cleft palate
    • Cardiac defects (e.g., TOF)
    • Hypocalcemia
    • Psychiatric issues: schizophrenia risk, learning disabilities

choices.text: Any amount of alcohol use is not recommended during pregnancy
Up to 3 standard drinks per day in pregnancy is not causative for fetal alcohol syndrome
More than 7 standard drinks per week in pregnancy can lead to fetal alcohol syndrome
Occasional use of alcohol during pregnancy is not harmful

questions.text: Fetal alcohol syndrome is a known preventable cause of intellectual disability. Which of the following is true about alcohol use in pregnant women?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism defines at-risk alcohol use for healthy nonpregnant women as > 3 drinks per occasion or > 7 drinks per week and any amount of drinking for women who are pregnant or at risk of pregnancy.(Option A & Option B ruled out)
  • There is no established safe threshold of alcohol consumption during pregnancy.
  • Prenatal alcohol exposure can impair fetal brain development at any level, leading to irreversible neurocognitive deficits.
  • Complete abstinence from alcohol throughout gestation is the only guaranteed way to prevent fetal alcohol spectrum disorders.(option D ruled out)
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Ethanol freely crosses the placenta; fetal alcohol dehydrogenase activity is low, prolonging fetal exposure to alcohol and its metabolites.
  • Clinical Spectrum:
    • Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) includes characteristic facial dysmorphology, growth restriction, and neurodevelopmental impairment (IQ deficits, attention problems).
    • Lesser exposure may result in Partial FAS or Alcohol-Related Neurodevelopmental Disorder, both carry risk of intellectual disability

Reference: Alcohol Use in Pregnancy (nih.gov)

questions.text: Wechsler's Intelligence Scale for Children can be applied to children of which age?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Wechsler Intelligence Test for Children (WISC) is standardized for children 6 to 16 years, providing reliable measures of verbal comprehension, perceptual reasoning, working memory, and processing speed.
  • Administering WISC to children younger than 6 risks invalid scores because the tasks assume school-age cognitive and attentional capacities.
  • For children between 3 - 6 years, The Wechsler Preschool and Primary Scale of Intelligence (WPPSI) is commonly used.
  • < 2½ years → Bayley Scales of Infant Development or Cattell Infant Intelligence Scale
  • Alternate Tests (Broader Age Ranges):
    • Stanford-Binet 4th Ed.: 2 years onward
    • Kaufman Assessment Battery: 2½-12½ years
    • Kaufman Adolescent & Adult Intelligence Test: 11-85 years

questions.text: DSM-5 includes all of the following specifiers in specific learning disorder except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to DSM-5,Specific Learning Disorder is a neurodevelopmental disorder that impairs the ability to learn or use academic skills, such as reading, writing, or mathematics, despite normal intelligence, adequate education, and opportunity.

DSM-5 specifiers in specific learning disorder:

  • With impairment in reading (dyslexia)
  • With impairment in written expression (dysgraphia)
  • With impairment in mathematics (dyscalculia)

Diagnostic Criteria (DSM-5):

  • Persistent difficulties in academic skills (reading, writing, arithmetic) for ≥ 6 months despite targeted interventions.
  • Affected skills are substantially below age-level expectations and interfere with academic achievement or daily living.

questions.text: Choose a correct treatment strategy for specific learning disability:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • According to DSM-5,Specific Learning Disorder is a neurodevelopmental disorder that impairs the ability to learn or use academic skills, such as reading, writing, or mathematics, despite normal intelligence, adequate education, and opportunity.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy, was referred for evaluation of failing to complete in-class assignments and homework and failing tests in reading, spelling and arithmetic. Which of the following step is not essential in obtaining certification in his case as per Rights of Persons with disabilities Act (RPWD)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Disability certification procedure as per the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act 2016 Screening:

  • The teachers of the public and private school shall carry out the screening in class III or at eight years of age, whichever is earlier.
  • The teacher approaches the screening committee headed by the principal(mandatory for both public and private schools).
  • The teachers shall interview the parents to assess their involvement and motivation regarding their child's education.
  • If the parents are motivated and the screening questionnaire suggests SLD, then the child should be referred for further assessment.
  • The child shall be referred to a pediatrician for an SLD assessment by the principal of the school with the recommendations of the screening committee endorsed.

Diagnosis: It involves a team approach involving a pediatrician and clinical or rehabilitation psychologist. This would involve three steps:

  • Step 1: Assessment by a pediatrician: The pediatrician will do the initial assessment. This will involve a detailed neurological examination including vision and hearing assessment. It has to be ensured that the child has normal vision and hearing acuity before proceeding to the next step.
  • Step 2: IQ Assessment: Child/clinical psychologist will do the IQ assessment (Option C ruled out)using MISIC or WISC-III. If the IQ is determined to be >85, then step 3 will be applied.
  • Step 3: SLD Assessment: NIMHANS battery shall be applied as a diagnostic test for SLD.(Option D ruled out)

Reference: Specific learning disability in the context of current diagnostic systems and policies in India: Implications for assessment and certification - PubMed (nih.gov)

questions.text: A number of known genetically caused syndromes include autism spectrum disorder as part of a broader phenotype. One of them could be:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A number of known genetically caused syndromes include autism spectrum disorder as part of a broader phenotype.
  • The most common of these inherited disorders is fragile X syndrome, an X-linked recessive disorder that is present in 2 to 3 percent of individuals with autism spectrum disorder.
  • Fragile X syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by a CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene.

Explanation of other options:

  • Williams syndrome(Option A)- Caused by 7q11.23 deletion. Characterized by "elfin" facies, cardiovascular anomalies, and hypersociability. not strongly linked to ASD
  • Cri-du-chat syndrome(Option B)- Caused by 5p deletion. Features include high-pitched cry, severe intellectual disability, and microcephaly, ASD not a core component.
  • Klinefelter's syndrome(Option D)- 47,XXY karyotype. Males have tall stature, hypogonadism, and learning difficulties but do not typically present with ASD as part of the syndrome.

questions.text: A biomarker identified in autism spectrum disorder is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The first biomarker identified in autism spectrum disorder was elevated serotonin in whole blood, almost exclusively in the platelets.
  • Platelets acquire 5-HT via the serotonin transporter (SERT, encoded by SLC6A4), a heritable mechanism also active in the brain.
  • Variants in the SERT gene and the 5-HT2A receptor gene (HTR2A) influence platelet and central serotonin regulation and are linked to ASD risk.
  • Because 5-HT is known to be involved in brain development, it is possible that the changes in 5-HT regulation may lead to alterations in neuronal migration and growth in the brain.
  • Genetic Links: Polymorphisms in SLC6A4 and HTR2A underlie both elevated platelet serotonin and ASD heritability.
  • Peripheral vs. Central: Although blood serotonin does not cross the blood-brain barrier, shared transporter/receptor biology suggests parallel central serotonergic dysfunction.
  • Clinical Implications: Serotonergic agents have limited efficacy on core ASD symptoms but may alleviate comorbid anxiety or repetitive behaviors.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy has presented with social communication difficulties and repeated stereotypical behaviours. Which of the following biomarkers could be identified in this boy?
I. Elevated histamine
II. Increased total brain volume
III. Theory of mind deficits
IV. Impaired occipital lobe processing
V. Impaired frontal lobe processing
VI. Dysfunction of mirror neuron system
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the given clinical scenario, the 7 year old presents with complaints of social communication difficulties and repeated stereotypical behaviour which are characteristic of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD).
  • Increased total brain volume in early childhood reflects atypical neuronal pruning and overgrowth in ASD.
  • Theory of mind deficits are a core cognitive impairment, leading to difficulty understanding other's perspectives.
  • Impaired frontal lobe processing manifests as reduced activation in left frontal regions during language and executive tasks.
  • Dysfunction of the mirror neuron system underlies deficits in imitation and social reciprocity.

Biomarkers in autism spectrum disorder:

  • Elevated serotonin in platelets
  • Increased total brain volume
  • Disruption of sensitive or critical periods within brain's plasticity
  • Theory of mind deficits
  • Tendency to scan faces differently than controls
  • Greater amygdala hyper-arousal
  • Dysfunction of mirror neuron system
  • Decreased activation of left frontal regions during memory and language-based tasks

questions.text: What percentage of autism spectrum children also have intellectual disability?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Approximately 30% of ASD cases meet criteria for intellectual disability (IQ <70 with adaptive deficits).
  • Within this subgroup:
    • ~30% have mild to moderate ID.
    • ~45-50% have severe to profound ID.
  • Intellectual disability in ASD correlates with greater support needs and influences educational placement.
  • Early assessment of cognitive function guides individualized intervention planning.

questions.text: Which two psychotropic medications have been approved by FDA for use in autism spectrum disorder?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Two second-generation antipsychotics, risperidone and aripiprazole, have been approved by the Food and Drug Administration(FDA) for treatment of irritability in individuals with autism spectrum disorder.
  • Mechanism of action: Risperidone works by blocking dopamine (D2) and serotonin (5-HT2A) receptors in the brain and Aripiprazole has a more balanced and flexible action. It partially stimulates dopamine (D2) and serotonin (5-HT1A) receptors, while blocking another serotonin receptor (5-HT2A).Thus stabilise mood and reduce irritability.
  • Dosage and Monitoring:
    • Risperidone: start 0.25-0.5 mg/day, titrate to 1-3 mg/day, monitor weight, metabolic profile, and prolactin.
    • Aripiprazole: start 1 mg/day, titrate to 5-15 mg/day, monitor similar parameters.
  • Side Effects: Weight gain, sedation, extrapyramidal symptoms, metabolic syndrome. Require regular monitoring.

questions.text: Which gene has been found to have association with ADHD?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Family studies and population-based studies have found an association between the dopamine 4 receptor seven-repeat allele gene(DRD4) gene and ADHD.
  • Most molecular research on ADHD has focused on genes that influence the metabolism or action of dopamine.
  • Other dopaminergic genes studied in ADHD: DAT1 (dopamine transporter), DRD5, and COMT.
  • Neurobiology of ADHD: Imbalance in catecholamine neurotransmission (dopamine and norepinephrine) in prefrontal circuits.

Explanation of other options:

PSEN1 (Presenilin-1)(Option B) A gene associated with early-onset familial Alzheimer's disease, involved in the production of beta-amyloid plaques through altered cleavage of amyloid precursor protein (APP).

DISC1 (Disrupted-in-Schizophrenia 1)(Option C): A gene linked to schizophrenia and mood disorders, involved in neuronal development, migration, and synapse formation.

APP (Amyloid Precursor Protein)(Option D): A gene whose abnormal processing leads to beta-amyloid accumulation in Alzheimer's disease, but it is not associated with ADHD.

He was very hyperactive and would not sit at his place in the class, would always be 'on the go', often made careless mistakes in his work, would start a task but quickly lose focus and his work would mostly be disorganised. Which of the following holds true for his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The symptoms described in the above question are suggestive of ADHD.
  • The major area of the brain implicated in ADHD is the prefrontal cortex. Functional and structural imaging studies consistently show prefrontal hypoactivity in ADHD.
  • Heritability is high, approximately 75%. (Option A ruled out)
  • Most common neurotransmitter implicated is (Option C ruled out)
  • DRD4 (dopamine D4 receptor) and DAT1 (dopamine transporter) variants are linked to ADHD risk. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is referred to a psychiatrist for management of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. His parents ask the psychiatrist about the prognosis and whether this condition persists into adulthood. In what percentage of children with ADHD, the symptoms persist even in adulthood?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Symptoms have been shown to persist into adolescence in 60 to 85 percent of cases and into adult life in approximately 40-50 percent of cases.
  • Adult ADHD often presents with more subtle symptoms: inattention and executive dysfunction rather than overt hyperactivity.
  • Early diagnosis and consistent treatment improve long-term functional outcomes.

questions.text: Psychiatrists often advise 'drug holidays' while prescribing methylphenidate for management of ADHD, that is children are given drug-free periods during weekends or vacations. This is done to cover up for the property of methylphenidate to cause:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chronic methylphenidate use can suppress appetite, leading to reduced weight gain and modest slowing of height growth.
  • Scheduled drug-free intervals allow children's appetites to recover, promoting "catch-up" growth.

Explanation of other options:

Rebound effect(Option B)- Manifests as temporary symptom return at dose trough, managed by timing or formulation adjustments.

Abuse potential(Option C)- Controlled via extended-release preparations and monitoring, holidays are not the primary strategy.

Insomnia(Option D)- Addressed by morning dosing and avoiding late-day doses rather than drug holidays.

choices.text: It should be given at night after meals
It should be given after the kid returns from school
It should be given just prior to the kid going to school
It can be given anytime during the day

questions.text: Which of the following advice would a psychiatrist give to parents while prescribing methylphenidate for ADHD?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Methylphenidate is formulated for once-daily morning dosing to cover school hours and afternoon activities.
  • Administering just before school ensures peak therapeutic levels during academic tasks when attention and behavior control are most needed.
  • Evening or irregular dosing risks insomnia and suboptimal daytime coverage.

Explanation of other options:

It should be given at night after meals(Option A) Night dosing leads to insomnia and disrupts sleep hygiene.

It should be given after the kid returns from school(Option B) After school dosing misses school hours when focus is most required.

It can be given anytime during the day(Option D): timing should align with daily functional demands and avoid evening intake.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy would often be bullied by his classmates as 'clumsy' as he would frequently drop objects on the floor, would bump into things, would have difficulty tying shoelaces and playing ball. What would be the appropriate diagnosis according to DSM-5?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Children with developmental motor coordination struggle to perform accurately the motor activities of daily life, such as jumping, hopping, running or catching a ball.
  • Children with coordination problems may also agonize to use utensils correctly, tie their shoelaces or write.
  • A child with developmental coordination disorder may exhibit delays in achieving motor milestones, such as sitting, crawling and walking, because of clumsiness and yet excel at verbal skills.
  • Developmental coordination disorder, thus, may be characterized by either clumsy gross and/or fine motor skills, resulting in poor performance in sports and even in academic achievement because of poor writing skills.
  • A child with developmental coordination disorder may bump into things more often than siblings or drop things.

Explanation of other options:

Gross motor disorder(Option B): is not a separate DSM-5 diagnosis.

Stereotypic movement disorder(Option C) involves repetitive, nonfunctional motor behaviors (e.g., hand flapping), not poor coordination.

No pathology(Option D) is incorrect, symptoms cause significant functional impairment.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with severe intellectual disability was evaluated after transferring to a new private school. During classroom observation, when prompted to engage in tasks that required removing his hands from his pockets, he began hitting his head with his hands. When his hands were held by the teacher, he used his knees to strike his head. He was remarkably flexible and could hit or kick himself in nearly any position, even while walking. Such self-injurious behavior is least likely to be seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Turner syndrome is not characteristically associated with self-injurious behaviors. It is a chromosomal disorder (45,X) affecting females only
  • Features:
    • Short stature, webbed neck, primary amenorrhea
    • Normal intelligence or mild learning disability, especially in math or spatial tasks

Explanation of other options:

  • Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome(Option A) X-linked recessive disorder caused by HGPRT enzyme deficiency. Features include:
    • Severe intellectual disability
    • Self-mutilation (e.g., biting lips/fingers, head banging)
    • Hyperuricemia (gout, nephrolithiasis)
    • Self-injury begins in early childhood and is persistent and compulsive.
  • Smith-Magenis Syndrome(Option B): It is caused by a deletion on chromosome 17. Features include:
    • Intellectual disability
    • Sleep disturbances (melatonin rhythm inversion)
    • Self-injurious behaviors: head banging, hand biting, etc.
    • Aggression and sensory integration issues
  • Prader-Willi Syndrome(Option C): It is due to loss of paternal chromosome 15q11-q13 (genomic imprinting disorder)
    • Key features:
    • Hypotonia, intellectual disability
    • Hyperphagia → obesity
    • Skin-picking is common

Reference: Self-injurious behaviour as part of genetic syndromes - PubMed(nih.gov)

questions.text: Production of tics in Tourette's disorder involves dysfunction of which region of brain?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tourette's disorder is a neurodevelopmental condition characterized by motor and vocal tics, and its underlying pathophysiology centers on dysfunction in specific brain regions like basal ganglia.
  • The basal ganglia, especially the caudate nucleus and putamen, are critical for motor control, habit formation, and inhibition of involuntary movements.
  • In Tourette's, there is dysregulation of dopamine neurotransmission within cortico-striatal-thalamic-cortical(CSTC)circuits involving the basal ganglia, leading to disinhibited motor output (i.e., tics).
  • Dopaminergic dysregulation within the striatum (a core component of the basal ganglia) drives tic generation
  • Neuroimaging and lesion studies consistently localize tic pathology to basal ganglia structures
  • CSTC loops:
    cortex → striatum → globus pallidus/substantia nigra → thalamus → cortex

Management:

  • Behavioral Therapy - First-line treatment
    • Comprehensive Behavioral Intervention for Tics (CBIT)
    • Includes Habit Reversal Training (HRT)
  • Recommended as the initial treatment, especially for mild to moderate tics
  • Pharmacotherapy - If tics are severe, disabling, or resistant to therapy
    • First-line pharmacological agents:
      • Risperidone - Most commonly used atypical antipsychotic
      • Aripiprazole - Fewer metabolic/EPS side effects; increasingly preferred
    • Alpha-2 agonists (especially with comorbid ADHD):
      • Clonidine

Explanation of the options:

Thalamus(Option B)- acts as a relay but is downstream in the circuit.

Hypothalamus(Option C)- not implicated in tic pathophysiology.

Cerebrum(Option D)- too broad; the specific subcortical basal ganglia are key.

questions.text: Identify complex vocal tic from the following:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Repeating words or phrases (like echolalia/palilalia) are complex vocal tics.

Motor and vocal tics are divided into simple and complex types:

  • Simple motor tics are those composed of repetitive, rapid contractions of functionally similar muscle groups-for example, eye-blinking, neck-jerking, shoulder-shrugging and facial-grimacing.
  • Common simple vocal tics include coughing, throat-clearing, grunting, sniffing, snorting and barking.
  • Complex motor tics appear to be more purposeful and ritualistic than simple tics. Common complex motor tics include grooming behaviours, the smelling of objects, jumping, touching behaviours, echopraxia(imitation of observed behaviour) and copropraxia(display of obscene gestures).
  • Complex vocal tics include repeating words or phrases out of context, coprolalia(use of obscene words or phrases), palilalia (a person's repeating his or her words) and echolalia(repetition of the last-heard words of others).

questions.text: Which of the following is a technique used in treatment of tic disorders?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Habit Reversal Training is used in management of tic disorders.
  • It involves several components aimed at increasing tic awareness, developing competing responses to tics and building and sustaining motivation and compliance.
  • 5 component HRT package:
    1. Awareness training: patient learns to detect premonitory urges or the earliest sign of a tic
    2. Competing-response training: patient performs a voluntary, physically incompatible behavior contingent on urge onset
    3. Motivation and generalization: self-monitoring, review of tic patterns, and practice across settings
    4. Contingency Management: Uses reward systems (token charts, verbal praise) and involves parents/teachers to reinforce successful use of competing responses and tic suppression.
    5. Generalization Training: Ensures skills transfer by practicing awareness, competing responses, and relaxation across multiple settings
  • Incorporated into Comprehensive Behavioral Intervention for Tics (CBIT) alongside relaxation and functional assessment
  • Behavioural disorders treated with HRT include tics, trichotillomania, nail biting, thumb sucking, skin picking, temporomandibular disorder(TMJ), lip-cheek biting and stuttering.

Explanation of other options:

Eye sensitisation(Option B)- no role in tic management.

Systematic desensitisation(Option C)- used for anxiety/phobias, not tics.

Hypnosis(Option D)- lacks strong evidence as a standalone tic therapy.

questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sertraline is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor used primarily for OCD and depression, not for tic reduction
  • First-line pharmacologic treatments for tics include antipsychotics and noradrenergic agents like Risperidone, Aripiprazole clonidine etc.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy attends a Tourette disorder clinic for evaluation of motor tics in the head and neck, occasional coughing and grunting and a new symptom of throat clearing many times per day. Which of the following statements holds false in his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This statement is false. The treatment relies on dopaminergic antagonists (e.g., risperidone, haloperidol) or VMAT2 inhibitors, not agonists
  • Agonists would worsen dopaminergic overactivity underlying tics
  • Tourette's disorder often co-occurs with other conditions. Over 50% of children meet ADHD criteria, and 20 - 40% meet full OCD criteria, reflecting shared neurobiological and genetic factors.
  • First-degree relatives of patients with OCD have been shown to have higher rates of tic disorders compared to the general population.
  • Habit Reversal Training is used in management of tic disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is found to be least comorbid with Tourette's disorder?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Schizophrenia is rarely associated with Tourette's. Psychotic disorders are not typical comorbidities.
  • Up to half of all patients with Tourette's disorder also have ADHD and up to 40 percent of those with Tourette's disorder also haveOCD.
  • These frequent comorbidities with Tourette's disorder can lead to a plethora of overlapping symptoms.
  • Because Tourette's disorder is frequently comorbid with attentional, obsessional and oppositional behaviours, these symptoms often emerge prior to the tics.

Explanation of other options:

  • Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD)(Option A): It is highly comorbid with Tourette's, particularly in cases with more complex tics or family history.Often shares underlying pathophysiology involving cortico-striato-thalamo-cortical circuits.
  • Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)(Option B) It is the most frequently associated disorder with Tourette's (seen in over 50% of cases). Often precedes the onset of tics and complicates clinical management.
  • Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD)(Option D) Common, Especially When ADHD is PresentODD often co-occurs in Tourette's patients, particularly when ADHD is also present, due to shared behavioral dysregulation.
